JAVASCRIPT.EXERCISE:
compile-time environment Knowledge about constants at compile time opens the door to many optimizations that allow us to generate more efficient object code. In addition to the extension of the compile-time environment from the exercise, we may store the value of a constant if it is known at compile time, or other information that can help us optimize the code.
Constant declarations such as const name = literal; allow us to replace all occurrences of name within the scope of the declaration directly by literal without having to perform a lookup in the runtime environment. This optimization is called constant propagation. Use an extended compile-time environment to store literal constants and modify compile_name to use the stored constant instead of applying lookup_symbol_value in the generated assign instruction. Hint: Implementing constant propagation as a transformation of the tagged-list representation of the program source is considerably easier than performing the optimization as part of code generation.
Function declaration is a derived component that expands to constant declaration, and all primitive functions are in the same frame of the global environment, which is known at compile time. If we further extend our compile-time environment to keep track of which names refer to compiled functions and which ones to primitive functions, we can move the test that checks whether a function is compiled or primitive from run time to compile time. This makes the object code more efficient because it replaces a test that must be performed once per function application in the generated code by one that is performed by the compiler. Use such an extended compile-time environment and modify compile_function_call so that only the instructions in the compound_branch or the primitive_branch are generated for a function call, if it can be determined at compile time that the called function is compiled or primitive.
Replacing constant names for their literal values following part (a) paves the way for another optimization, namely replacing applications of primitive functions to known constants with the compile-time computed result. This optimization is called constant folding and replaces expressions such as 40 + 2 by 42 by performing the addition directly in the compiler. Extend the compiler to perform constant folding for arithmetic operations on numbers and string concatenation. Can your optimization replace 1 + 2 + 3 by the constant 6? Is the hint for part (a) also useful for constant folding?
Constant folding may produce additional constant values that can be propagated through the program. Extend the compiler to transform code like the following
const x = 1; const y = x + 2; f(y);
by repeated application of constant propagation and constant folding into the final program
f(3);
